urn:contentItem:60KB-6BR1-F0J6-J0D8-00000-00Burn set for Lake Boort2020-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Burn set for Lake BoortChris Pedler

A cultural burn will be carried out by Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA this weekend.

The burn will be 24 hectares in size in the area between Lake Boort and Little Lake Boort from 10am on Friday to 8pm on Sunday. Smoke may be visible from the Boort township during these times. Anyone experiencing any symptoms from smoke exposure should seek medical advice.

For more information visit www.vic.gov.au/plannedburns

urn:contentItem:61F9-C6S1-F0JP-W3WV-00000-0017 more to fight fires2020-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 617 more to fight firesOlivia Shying

FOREST Fire Management Victoria's new seasonal recruits in the Otway District are taking part in extensive training to protect communities from bushfires.

The 17 recruits are among 47 project firefighters (PFF) employed in the Otway District- for the summer and stationed at the Gellibrand, Colac, Barwon Downs, Apollo Bay, Lorne and Anglesea depots-.

Their training covers essential elements of firefighting, including fire behaviour, suppression, planned burning, safety and survival techniques.

Four-wheel-drive training has also commenced, with recruits driving firefighting vehicles across a range of terrains at Anglesea last week and Barwon Downs this week. This season there have been 740 FFMVics employed, an increase of 140 from last year to help meet the unique challenges of 2020.

urn:contentItem:60P9-PM81-JD34-V3F7-00000-00Officials plan burn in Hunter2020-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Officials plan burn in Hunter

FOREST Fire Management and the Country Fire Authority say there will be a planned burn near Elmore from Friday. About four hectares will be burned at the Hunter Elmore-Cohuna rail line bushland reserve in Hunter. The Dja Dja Wurrung will start the cultural burn at 10am on Friday, if weather permits. The burn is expected to last until 8pm on Monday. Residents in Hunter, Drummartin, and Elmore may see smoke from the burn until Wednesday. For more information, visit plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:62R1-3MP1-JBR4-F3FF-00000-00CFA fleet, radio get Budget upgrades2021-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:35ZLexisNexisCFA fleet, radio get Budget upgrades

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt

CFA volunteers have gained a much needed $22-million boost to upgrading their ageing tankers.

Today's Victorian Budget outlined an extra $12.75m on top of the $9.688m already committed to upgrading the CFA truck fleet in 2021-22.

But the allocation is a one-off commitment that still falls well short of the $29m a year that is needed replace 120 tankers a year over the next 10 to 13 years to ensure none of them is more than 20 years old.

Early last year the The Weekly Times reported then CFA chief officer Steve Warrington had called on the Government for an extra $200 million over the next decade to upgrade the CFA tankers, but still no long-term commitment has been made.

As it stands many brigades are operating trucks that 25 to 30 or more years old.

The Budget also allocated another $138.8m over seven years to replace the CFA's radio equipment with modern digital technology, to ensure it can communicate with Fire Rescue Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria brigades.

Local CFA brigades will also benefit from the replacement of the Irymple, Serpentine and Metcalfe stations.

The Doreen station will also be refurbished, while Edithvale station gains new equipment.

urn:contentItem:60GF-6TT1-JD3N-5046-00000-00Bushfire fuel cleared away2020-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Bushfire fuel cleared away

EXTENSIVE mulching work has been completed along the Great Ocean Road to reduce bushfire risk across coastal towns.

Forest Fire Management Victoria finished work to clear flammable vegetation across Ocean Grove, Anglesea, Aireys Inlet, Lorne, Wye River, Separation Creek and Kennett River this week.

The program was rolled out across the Otway District in March after a four-year trial in which heavy-duty machinery was tested on vegetation in the region. FFMVic Otway district manager David Roberts said the works would pave the way for future planned burning.

urn:contentItem:5YYD-JKT1-F0J6-J1TW-00000-00Fox baits planted in forests2020-05-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisFox baits planted in forests

Forest Fire Management Victoria will plant temporary fox baits across state forests to reduce attacks on wildlife and livestock.

The baits are in Maryborough, Sedgwick, Lockwood, Lyal and Kimbolton.

FFM Victoria forest and roading officer Joseph Rogasch said foxes are a threat to biodiversity and native animals.

"They also hinder threatened native species recovery and re-introduction programs," Mr Rogasch said. The baits were buried on Wednesday and will be removed on June 17.

urn:contentItem:61MY-X3B1-JD34-V273-00000-00Firefighters control 200-hectare blaze2020-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Firefighters control 200-hectare blazeEmma D'Agostino and Chris Pedler

FIRE investigators have been notified after a 200-hectare blaze impacted a house and a number of hay sheds near Colbinabbin yesterday afternoon.

Rushworth CFA captain Mark Jones said the fire started at multiple points along Bendigo-Murchison Road before winds swept it north.

"It's unclear what started it," Mr Jones said.

He was unsure of the extent of the damage to the affected house, which was near Bendigo-Murchison Road.

Mr Jones said a couple of hay sheds along Heathcote-Rochester Road went up in flames.

Ten tankers and air support were initially called to the blaze.

Twenty additional CFA units and a number of Forest Fire Management Victoria vehicles arrived on scene to assist.

Mr Jones said the two helitak air support crews picked up a fair bit and did a great job.

"The fire was running pretty hard, it was just a good thing we had so many trucks available straight away and the aircraft," he said.

urn:contentItem:61M8-S0C1-JD34-V002-00000-00Grass fire forces out campers2020-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Grass fire forces out campersDavid Estcourt

Holidaymakers were forced to evacuate yesterday as a grass fire burned out of control in Victoria's north-west.

A grassfire burning about seven kilometres south-west of Robinvale, a town close to the Murray River and popular with campers, forced holidaymakers from the area.

Emergency Management Victoria issued a Watch and Act alert at 4.37pm yesterday, warning people the bushfire was travelling north-easterly and was not yet under control.

"The fire has burnt about 18 hectares and is generating a lot of smoke and embers," a CFA spokeswoman said last night.

"More than 20 vehicles, including tankers and strike teams, are responding to the fire. Crews are focusing on asset protection and will be working throughout the night."

The CFA was supporting the operation, which was being led by Forest Fire Management.

A total fire ban had been declared for yesterday in the Mallee, Wimmera, Northern Country and North Central districts.

A planned cultural burn will begin near Boort on Wednesday. Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA will help carry the 12-hectare burn at Woolshed Swamp about six kilometres south of Boort between April 22 and April 29. Two planned burns will be carried out in the Little Desert near Kaniva on Friday. Forest Fire Management Victoria has advised that a 144ha fuel reduction burn will be carried out on the McDonalds Highway - Plains Track, 21km South East of Kaniva. A 409ha fuel reduction burn will also take place on the Broughtons Track- Sister Hill Track, 25 km south east of Kaniva.

The burns should be completed between 11am and 8pm, weather permitting. Smoke may be visible from both operations into Saturday.

urn:contentItem:60SS-2RH1-F0JP-W08T-00000-00Fire season flares up2020-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Fire season flares up

A FIRE burnt through grassland about 20km south of Ballarat on Monday night in what was one of the first in regional Victoria since the deadly bushfires in January.

The small fire took hold about 6.35pm near the town of Buninyong. It was declared under control by 7.45pm, Fire Rescue Victoria said. The cause of the fire was being investigated by Forest Fire Management Victoria. Bushfires burnt more than 1.5 million hectares in Victoria last summer and killed five people. Monday night's fire came amid a weather warning for damaging winds. The State Emergency Service said in the 24 hours to 10pm Monday it responded to 122 call-outs, 86 of which were for fallen trees on property.

urn:contentItem:618R-9DK1-JD34-V393-00000-00Illegal campfire patrol blitz2020-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Illegal campfire patrol blitzJuanita Greville

If you are heading to the Grampians to camp this weekend, know your campfire safety rules.

Checks in the region will target illegal campfires as patrols are stepped up.

About 10 per cent of all bushfires are caused by campfire negligence.

Popular camping and recreation areas from Lake Burrumbeet through to the Rocklands reservoir area, on the western side of the Grampians range, will be part of the crackdown by Conservation Regulator officers and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Officers will look for unsafe campfires to prevent bushfires being started by negligence and penalise people found in breach.

"All too often we see the consequences of people ignoring campfire safety rules, with approximately ten per cent of all bushfires caused by campfire negligence," Brian Hamer, Manager Regulatory Operations, said.

"It is a serious offence to leave a fire unattended, even for a short while, as most campfires escape when left unattended."

urn:contentItem:60HR-44G1-F0JP-W4J8-00000-00Firefighter jobs on offer2020-08-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Firefighter jobs on offer

AS THE state's unemployment numbers continue to soar, the Andrews government has begun recruiting forest firefighters to help protect their communities and the environment this season.

Energy, Environment and Climate Change Minister Lily D'Ambrosio said applications had opened for Victorians of all backgrounds to join Forest Fire Management Victoria as seasonal project firefighters.

The recruitment drive off-ers employment, training and career opportunities for suitable applicants in regional communities.

Successful applicants will join a highly skilled team of more than 1000 frontline forest firefighters ready to keep Victorians safe. Applications for Project Firefighters close on Sunday, August 23. For further information and to apply, visit ffm.vic.gov.au or call 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5YW8-Y3C1-F0J6-J1S1-00000-00Trees now firewood for locals2020-05-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisTrees now firewood for localsEllen Ebsary

A bushfire in Langi Ghiran State Park on Wednesday was close to culturally significant Indigenous sites.

Country Fire Authority District 16 operations officer Neville Collins said CFA crews initially responded to the one hectare fire at Lagoon Track before handing it over to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

He said Parks Victoria staff were called to ensure they knew where the scar trees and rock art were before they used bulldozers and waterbombing aircraft.

urn:contentItem:5XYN-KTF1-JD3N-52HR-00000-00ANOTHER HERO LOST2020-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9ANOTHER HERO LOST

FIREFIGHTER DIESA VICTORIAN firefighter who died while battling blazes in East Gippsland has been identified as long-serving Wonthaggi veteran Bill Slade, who marked 40 decades of service just months ago. Mr Slade, 60, was struck and killed by a falling tree at Anglers Rest, near Omeo, while working with a forest fire management taskforce to consolidate the fire edge on Saturday. He is the fourth firefighter to die this bushfire season.

1583: The first life insurance policy is taken out in London. 1836: Adelaide's first paper, the South Australian Gazette and Colonial Register, is printed.

1943: The Australian government announces Australia is no longer threatened with invasion by the Japanese.

1983: Sally Ride becomes America's first woman in space as she and four colleagues blast off aboard the space shuttle Challenger.

2006: Spain's Catalonia region votes overwhelmingly in favour of a statute giving it more autonomy.

2017: A forest fire in Portugal kills 19 people, most of them trapped in cars caught in the blaze. Birthdays: Paul McCartney, British singer (1942-); Alison Moyet, British singer (1961-); Cameron Smith, Australian NRL player (1983-); Billy Slater, Australian NRL player (1983-).

urn:contentItem:6198-D7M1-JD3N-54R7-00000-00FUNDAY BOOK WORM2020-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 8FUNDAY BOOK WORMReviews by Sandy Fussell, www.sandyfussell.com

A DIFFERENT LAND Paul Jennings This easy-read book is the story of a mother and two boys who have escaped war. They find themselves detained in an Australian migrant hostel unable to leave unless Pat gets a job. Crayfish, who runs the isolated bush store at Booley Bool West, is not expecting a cultured lady like Patricia to answer his ad. He thought Pat was a "bloke". A bush adventure of Australianisms, snakes and wild pigs, snags on the barbie, long-drop pit toilets, floods, and ultimately cultural and gender acceptance.

Ages 9-14

THE BIG OLD RAMBUTAN TREE Kathy Creamer Ginger, the orang-utan, is enjoying the Rambutan Tree's delicious new fruit. A crying animal distracts her. Her friends are appalled when she decides to look after the tiger cub. As it grows, its need for meat sees Ginger send Stripes away to be a tiger. Years later a forest fire traps Ginger, and a giant tiger leaps towards her. Stripes saves Ginger this time. A gentle story about kind deeds and unlikely friends. Ages 4-6

urn:contentItem:5XYD-RJ91-JBF5-T20C-00000-00Victorian firefighter dies near Omeo as Australia's fires crisis continues2020-01-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisVictorian firefighter dies near Omeo as Australia's fires crisis continues

A Victorian firefighter has died while working on a blaze near Omeo.

Chris Hardman, chief fire officer at Forest Fire Management Victoria, said the firefighter was involved in an incident while working in the area around the East Gippsland town.

"Family and fellow emergency personnel are being informed and will be supported," Mr Hardman said.

Victoria Police will investigate the matter and prepare a report for the coroner.

More to come.

urn:contentItem:61D1-J3P1-F0JP-W3D9-00000-00Be fire smart in Otways2020-11-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 31Be fire smart in Otways

FOREST Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) firefighters responded to 25 fires caused by illegal campfires in the Otways and in bush along the Great Ocean Road in the past year.

Campfire negligence causes about 10 per cent of all bushfires in Victoria, putting communities and firefighters at risk.

Campfires must not be lit on total fire ban days.

"The risk is real, and all campers have a responsibility to know and abide by campfire rules," FFMVic Otway district manager David Roberts said.

In state forests, campers must use a purpose-built fireplace, if provided, or a trench at least 30cm deep. In national and state parks, campfires may only be lit in purpose-built fireplaces provided.

Campfires need to be extinguished with water. If a fire is cool to touch, it is safe to leave.

FFMVic and the Conservation Regulator are undertaking patrols in and around campgrounds across the Otways, including sites near Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Forrest. On-the-spot fines of $496 can be issued to people breaching campfire safety rules. The maximum penalty for lighting a fire during a total fire ban is $39,652, two years' jail or both.

urn:contentItem:5XXV-9D31-JD34-V46M-00000-00Bass marathon cut short2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 13Bass marathon cut short

Lifesavers cut short their bi-ennial George Bass Surfboat Marathon to aid in evacuations.

On day three of the seven-day competition, the crews would have been scheduled to row into Bermagui, but at the same time, Bermagui was preparing evacuations toward Bega as the Badja Forest fire loomed.

But instead of just calling it quits, surf crews from across the coast quickly got involved in helping everyone safely head out of town and have since been able to get home safely.

urn:contentItem:61M8-NW71-DY19-C001-00000-00'Don't wait': Campers evacuated as uncontrolled grass fire burns in Victoria's north-west2020-12-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexis'Don't wait': Campers evacuated as uncontrolled grass fire burns in Victoria's north-westDavid Estcourt

Holidaymakers have been forced to evacuate as a grass fire burns out of control near Robinvale.

Holidaymakers have been forced to evacuate as a grassfire burns out of control in Victoria's north-west.

A fire burning about seven kilometres south-west of Robinvale, a town close to the Murray River and popular with campers, has forced holidaymakers from the area.

Emergency Management Victoria issued a "watch and act" alert at 4.37 on Sunday afternoon, warning people the bushfire was travelling north-easterly and that the fire was not yet under control.

"The fire has burnt about 18 hectares and is generating a lot of smoke and embers," a CFA spokeswoman said.

"More than 20 vehicles, including tankers and strike teams, are responding to the fire. Crews are focusing on asset protection and will be working throughout the night."

The CFA is supporting the operation, which is being led by Forest Fire Management.

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option," the warning reads, "conditions may change and get worse very quickly."

"Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

A total fire ban was declared for Sunday in the Mallee, Wimmera, Northern Country and North Central districts.

More to come

urn:contentItem:61BH-S351-JD3N-502R-00000-00A year on, bushfire pain lingers2020-11-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:35ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 23A year on, bushfire pain lingers

VICTORIA has marked a year since the horror Black Summer bushfires, which claimed five lives and destroyed hundreds of homes, with messages of reflection and resilience.

On November 21, 2019, dry lightning strikes in East Gippsland sparked three wildfires which became an inferno that burned for months, devouring more than 1.5 million hectares.

It led to the first code-red fire level warning for almost a decade in the Mallee and Northern Country fire districts.

The CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria paid tribute to those who died in the devastating season, including three FFMVic -firefighters.

CFA acting chief officer Garry Cook said the grim anniversary was a challenging day for Victorians displaced by the fires, as well as first responders.

"As we head into another fire season, the next couple of months will no doubt bring back some painful memories for many Victorians," he said.

"I hope this can be a time for solace and reflection for anyone who worked on or was impacted by the fires." He said the CFA had taken many lessons from the 2019-20 season and was prepared to protect communities again.

urn:contentItem:60N1-WG61-F0J6-J3NP-00000-00Pig cull wipes out 64 pests in North East region as part of three year plan2020-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisPig cull wipes out 64 pests in North East region as part of three year planVivienne Jones

More than 60 feral pigs were killed on public land in targeted locations across north-east Victoria.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume planning manager invasive species David Pasztaleniec said 64 of the pests were trapped and killed, many of them pregnant, in state forests and national parks in the Tatong, Samaria and Strathbogie areas.

"Feral pigs pose a serious threat to agriculture productivity and the environment, so this work is critical in protecting the land," he said.

"We are also working with landowners, especially those who adjoin public land, to better understand the level of impacts the pigs are having."

Mr Pasztaleniec said the three-year project used remote cameras and satellite tracking to pinpoint pig movements.

"They are a pest for farmers, because they can carry a number of diseases which can kill livestock and their feeding behaviour can heavily degrade agricultural land," he said

urn:contentItem:5XXS-26M1-DXX7-H1CH-00000-00Victorian bushfires official death toll rises to three as authorities confirm car accident was fire-related2020-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisVictorian bushfires official death toll rises to three as authorities confirm car accident was fire-related

The official death toll in Victoria's bushfire crisis has risen to three, authorities have confirmed.

Forest Fire Management Victoria staff member Matt Kavanagh, 43, died in a car accident last Friday.

An investigation has concluded it was because of fires.

Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said Mr Kavanagh and his colleague were involved in a two-vehicle crash on the Goulburn Valley Highway.

"Tragically, the 43-year-old couldn't be revived and died at the scene," she said.

Ms Neville said his colleague was taken to hospital in a stable condition.

More to come.

urn:contentItem:60K4-4WK1-JD34-V20Y-00000-00Planned cultural burn to be conducted at Mysia2020-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisPlanned cultural burn to be conducted at MysiaChris Pedler

A PLANNED burn in Mysia near Wedderburn will take place on Thursday and Friday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA will conduct the burn between 10am on Thursday and 8pm on Friday.

The cultural burn will be Mysia-Old Boort Road, 2.9 kilomters south west of Mysia and will be 7.6 hectares in size.

Nearby residents may see smoke Mysia and Borung. Anyone experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice.

Roads in the are may be hazardous due to low visibility from smoke. Drivers should follow all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

For more information visit www.vic.gov.au/plannedburns

urn:contentItem:6076-8HD1-F0JP-W1RK-00000-00Otways tracks closed2020-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 29Otways tracks closed

SOME tracks and roads across the Great Otway National Park and Otway Forest Park have been temporarily closed to traffic to protect the road and track network from damage during the wetter months.

The closures are also put in place for driver safety and to maintain water quality in rivers, creeks and reservoirs.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria put the seasonal road closures in place across winter and spring.

Most of the roads and tracks will be reopened in time for the Melbourne Cup weekend in November, but the closure period may be extended due to weather conditions.

Closures in the Otway Ranges include: GENTLE Annie Track, Aireys Inlet; COWLEY Track, Barwon Downs; BUNKER Hill Track, Gellibrand; and, HOLY Water Track, Lavers Hill.

To plan a trip and check road closures in state forests and forest parks, visit ffm.vic.gov.au/visiting-state-forests/forest-and-road-closures. For informational on seasonal closures in parks, visit parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/closures/seasonal-road-closures2

urn:contentItem:5YNR-P9D1-F0J6-J16F-00000-00Recovery continues in the Upper Murray2020-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:36ZLexisNexisRecovery continues in the Upper MurrayVivienne Jones

More than 260 kilometres of fencing has been replaced by Forest Fire Management Victoria since the Upper Murray bushfires earlier this year.

And the recovery effort is ongoing with teams continuing to assist with fencing, track clearing and hazardous tree removal.

Upper Murray district manager Dave Jenson said this had been a "very difficult time" and communities across the region had had a lot to deal with

"We want to reassure the community that our crews are continuing with bushfire recovery efforts, both safely out in the field and remotely, to ensure these priority programs continue," he said.

Mr Jenson said there had been 101 successful fencing funding applications completed.

"Many landowners that have had fencing affected have still not taken up the opportunity for funding, so I encourage people to contact us," he said.
